attributes.title: Linking Justification and Mood Following a Self-Control Dilemma

q1.value: The Influence of Justification on Mood Following a Self-Control Dilemma

q2.value: Ally M Heiland, Jennifer Veilleux, Morgan A. Hill

q3.value: This study aims to examine the affective impact of using justification to facilitate self-control failure. To do this, we will manipulate the presence of justification thinking in a hypothetical temptation situation that participants will read that involves a decision of whether or not the participant engages in exercise, and measure their affective responses.

q4.value: We predict a main effect of justification thinking on higher rates of self-control failure (i.e. choosing not to exercise). We would also predict that participants in the justification condition will report less negative affect and more positive affect following a decision to fail at self-control compared to participants who were not prompted with justification thinking.  Finally, we predict that people in the justification condition will report greater justification thinking.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a between subjects design with one factor (justification thinking) at two levels (justification thinking vs. no justification).

q9.value: We will use randomization procedures using Qualtrics. At the beginning of the study, participants will be randomly assigned on the back end to either “justification” or “no justification” thinking conditions where we will request an approximately equal number of participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited online using Prolific. Participants who are located in the United States will be eligible to participate .  We will also use in-study screening where we will ask people to report on several life goals, and we will only include participants who indicate a goal for physical fitness at a 3 or higher (on a 0 to 6 scale) reflecting fitness as a moderate goal.  Participants will be paid at a $9/hr rate for participation, which for a 4 minute study will result in .60 per person.

q13.value: We will recruit 300 people for this study, with the idea that perhaps ¼ of them will not have the requisite fitness goals, thus aiming for a sample size of 225.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .85 power to detect a medium effect size (w) of .20 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: We will run to get 225 people after exclusions—this may involve looking only at the goal data to evaluate inclusion and then run additional participants to get up to 225.

question.value: Using a hypothetical scenario design, half of the participants will be instructed to imagine themselves thinking justification type thoughts (e.g. “I was already good today”) while pondering a decision of whether or not to exercise, while the other half will read an identical scenario without the justification thoughts.

We will measure the baseline mood (positive and negative affect) of the participants at the beginning of the study. Participants will then be presented with a hypothetical self-control dilemma where they are confronted with a choice of whether to exercise. Following the presentation of the dilemma, participants will answer the question, “Do you work out, or do you go directly home?” by choosing one of two options: “Home” or “Work out.” We will again measure positive and negative mood following the dichotomous decision of whether or not to work out. We will also measure participants’ perceived self-control (Brief Self-Control Scale). Finally, we will have participants report their endorsement of various justification thoughts (adapted from Taylor, Webb, & Sheeran, 2014) on three subscales: deservingness (“I deserve a rest”), compensatory behaviors (“I’ll make up for it later”), and avoidance desire (“It’s too hard to say “yes” too”).
Each of the three indicies of justification thinking will be averaged to form an index score.  The items on the Brief Self-Control Scale will also be combined into an average self-control score.

Using a chi-sqaure test, we will examine the effect of justification condition on decision of whether to work out. We will examine the combined effect of justification and decision on change in positive affect over time. In addition, we will examine the combined effect of justification and decision on change in negative affect over time. We will also examine the partial correlation between post-decision affect (both positive and negative) and each index of justification thinking, controlling for pre-decision affect. Finally, we will examine the combined effect of justification and decision on each index of justification thinking.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criterion to determine if the analyses suggest statistically significant differences.

q22.value: We will exclude participants who answer a manipulation check question about the self-control situation incorrectly (“In the scenario described above, what did the vignette suggest that “you” were thinking in the situation?”). We will also exclude participants who indicate that they have completed the study before, that they didn’t pay attention to the study materials, and those who tell us to not keep their data.

q24.value: We will examine the correlational relationship between mood and justification thinking based on justification condition.   We may also look at self-control as a moderator of the predicted effects.

attributes.title: Pragmatic Enrichment with Semantically Exhaustive Alternatives

q1.value: The Role of Canonical and Exhaustive Alternative Salience

q3.value:
Rees and Bott (2018) report the results of a scalar implicature priming experiment (their Experiment 1) employing a paradigm and procedure similar to that of Bott and Chemla (2016). Replicating the results of Bott and Chemla, the authors find that interpretations of the semantically lower-bounded quantifier 'some', cardinal numbers, and existential expressions (of the form "There is an X") can be modulated when participants are biased to associate these expressions with (non-)exhaustive meanings on priming trials. 

The current study investigates whether and how interpretation of the expressions investigated by Rees and Bott  can be modulated by 1) exposing participants to expressions that are canonical pragmatic alternatives to the expressions of interest (e.g. 'all' as a canonical pragmatic alternative to 'some'); or by 2) exposing participants to expressions that semantically encode exhaustivity on the scale of interest (e.g. 'some but not all,' 'only some'). 1) corresponds to the 'Alternative' priming of Rees and Bott (2018); 2) corresponds to three novel priming types that we will explore in the present study.

q4.value:
The following hypotheses are advanced for each of the priming types we investigate in the present study (Weak, Strong, Alternative, Exhaustive-only, Exhaustive-subclausal, Exhaustive-clausal).

(1) The null hypothesis: between the priming condition and baseline condition, no differences in the extent to which "some", cardinal numbers, and existential expressions are interpreted exhaustively.

(2) The 'exhaustivity attenuation' hypothesis: "some", cardinal numbers, and existential expressions are interpreted less exhaustively after priming relative to our baseline condition. 

(3) The 'exhaustivity strengthening' hypothesis: "some", cardinal numbers, and existential expressions are interpreted more exhaustively after priming relative to our baseline condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Following Rees and Bott, our study will feature a repeated measures design. There will be three types of expression (some, number, ad-hoc), for which we will test six types of prime (strong, weak, alternative, exhaustive-only, exhaustive-subclausal, exhaustive-clausal),  plus a baseline priming condition.

However, as a between-subjects manipulation, we restrict the kinds of of priming conditions that a given participant sees during the experiment. Each participant will see 3 (expression) * 4 (prime) = 12 conditions. Participants in the 'alternative' condition see weak, strong, alternative, and baseline priming types; participants in the 'exhaustive-only' condition see weak, strong, exhaustive-only, and baseline priming types; participants in the 'exhaustive-subclausal' condition see weak, strong, exhaustive-subclausal, and baseline priming types; participants in the 'exhaustive-clausal' condition see weak, strong, exhaustive-clausal, and baseline priming types. 

Every prime type is realized in the form of three-trial blocks, presented in sequence, involving two priming trials and one target trial. Following Rees and Bott, participants see four unique 'priming blocks' for every condition, where the blocks are balanced for position of the correct image in the preceding two priming trials (left-left, right-right, left-right, or right-left). Thus, every condition will be realized in 3 (expression) * 4 (position of correct image on priming trials)  = 12 blocks, for a total of 48 blocks. 

Strong and weak priming blocks will be identical in character to the conditions described by Rees and Bott; the three exhaustive prime types will feature - on priming trials - expressions which semantically encode an exhaustive meaning; following Rees and Bott, the alternative priming type will feature a canonical pragmatic alternative on the scale of interest (see primingSI-materials.pdf for more details). Baseline prime blocks will consist of target trials, preceded by two math problems which participants are asked to solve on sequential slides. 

Additionally, following Rees and Bott, participants will see 48 filler blocks (of the same kind delivered to participants in their Experiment 1). These filler blocks match the structure of the 48 critical condition blocks described above, except that on the target trial, the choice is between a false image and 'Better Picture?'

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: For each between-subjects condition, we collected responses from 8 participants (excluded from the main experiment) in order to confirm that the experiment script was functioning properly.

question.value: We will recruit participants using Amazon Mechanical Turk (US IP addresses, minimum 95% prior approval rating).

q14.value: 100 would be the number of participants in Rees and Bott's study. We add 20 to that number, anticipating that data collected online will be noisier than the data that Rees and Bott collected in the lab. We quadruple that value (120), reflecting the fact that we have four between-subjects conditions for which we would like 120 participants.

question.value:
- Prime (levels: weak, strong, alternative, exhaustive-only, exhaustive-subclausal, exhaustive-clausal, baseline)
- Expression (levels: some, cardinal numbers, ad hoc)

We will measure image selection on target trials, which (following Rees & Bott) will contain a weak image and the option of "Better Picture?" 

The linking assumption for behavior on target trials is specified as follows: if participants considered the exhaustive meaning of the basic category expression to be more likely than the non-exhaustive meaning, they select the "Better Picture?" option; otherwise, they select the weak picture.

Within the four between-subjects conditions: mixed effects logistic regression predicting log odds of image selection on target trials from fixed effects of prime, category, and their interaction, with the maximal random effects structure justified by the design (random by-item and by-subject intercepts and slopes for prime, category, and their interaction). 

We will use the Bayesian implementation of mixed effects logistic regression using the BRMS package in R. (We will use the default parameter priors provided by the BRMS package).

q21.value: 95% credible intervals of coefficients from the mixed-effects models.

q22.value:
We will follow Rees and Bott in excluding a given participant's data in conditions where that participant answers incorrectly on at least one of the two priming trials in that condition. 

'Incorrectly' is operationalized as follows: on strong priming trials, we consider the incorrect selection to be the weak image, which (while semantically consistent with the trial's sentence) is dis-preferred to the strong image (which is consistent with both the core semantics and pragmatically-enriched meaning of the trial's sentence); on weak priming trials, the false image is incorrect; on alternative priming trials, the weak image is incorrect; on exhaustive priming trials (all three types), the strong image is incorrect. 

We will not exclude data from the baseline prime condition based on performance on priming trials.

q24.value:
Exploratory analyses will involve pairwise comparisons of identical priming types in 
the between-subjects conditions, e.g pairwise comparison between strong priming in the 'alternative' condition and strong priming in the 'exhaustive-only' condition, using the mixed effects logistic regression model described above.

attributes.title: Spillover Bias in Diversity Judgments
attributes.description: A project to replicate, extend, and explain the spillover bias in diversity judgments originally demonstrated by Daniels et al. (2017)

q1.value: Spillover Bias in Diversity Judgments - Conceptual Replication of Daniels et al. (2017)

q3.value: Daniels et al. (2017) demonstrated a spillover bias in diversity judgments. When people judge the diversity of a group on one dimension (e.g., race), their judgments tend to be affected by diversity on other dimensions (e.g., gender). The present study is a conceptual replication of this effect using a paradigm similar to one that we have used to study the effect of sample size on judgments of average (e.g., Price et al., 2014). It is essentially a direct replication of a study we conducted in the fall of 2019, which was successful (producing a clear spillover bias) except that the computer program contained an error so that the wrong stimuli were presented under one of the nine conditions.

q4.value: The hypothesis is that participants' mean judgments of the ethnoracial diversity of several stimulus groups will increase as a function of the gender diversity of those groups.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will see several groups of 10 photos taken from the Chicago Face Database (Ma, Correll, and Wittenbrink, 2015). For each stimulus group, they will judge the "racial/ethnic diversity" of the group by clicking on a visual analog scale. The stimulus groups will vary in terms of their objective ethnoracial diversity (1 non-White person, 3 non-White people, or 5 non-White people) but also in terms of their objective gender diversity (1 woman, 3 women, or 5 women). Each of the nine unique combinations of ethnoracial and gender diversity will be presented six times--in a new randomized order for each participant--for a total of 54 trials. In essence, the design is a 3 (ethnoracial diverstiy) x 3 (gender diversity) within-subjects factorial design, with the dependent variable being judgments of ethnoracial diversity.

q9.value: This is a within-subjects design in which each participant sees six groups representing the nine different combinations of objective ethnoracial and gender diversity. Randomization still occurs, however, in two ways. First, the order of the groups is determined randomly for each participant, with the constraint that each of the nine combinations occurs twice in the first 18 trials, twice in the second 18 trials, and twice in the third 18 trials. Second, the photographs that make up the groups are chosen randomly on each trial from a set of 192 photographs (96 White people and 96 non-White people) from the Chicago Face Database.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The participants will be recruited from an introductory psychology subject pool at California State University, Fresno, and they will receive credit toward a class assignment for their participation. All participants who sign up for the study and then arrive to the lab on time will be tested on individual desktop computers. The entire procedure will take about 20 minutes. Testing will begin in February 2020 and last about a month.

q13.value: We will test a minimum of 60 participants.

q14.value: First, the pilot study with 62 participants produced a strong (partial eta-squared = .24) and statistically significant spillover bias (defined as a positive linear effect of gender diversity on judgments of ethnoracial diversity). Second, a sensitivity power analysis conducted using G*Power's "Generic F Test" option shows that a sample of 60 would have a power of .95 to detect an effect with a non-centrality parameter as low as 13.43 (compared to 19.42 in the pilot study).

q15.value: We will stop testing participants when we reach our minimum of 60 and have tested any additional participants who were already scheduled at that point. (We post more than the minimum number of appointment times to account for no-shows.) Experience suggests that the final sample size will be between 60 and 70.

question.value: We will manipulate the ethnoracial diversity of the stimulus groups; they will have either one, three, or five non-White people in them. We will also manipulate the gender diversity of the stimulus groups; they will have either one, three, or five women in them. Both of these variables will be manipulated within subjects in a 3x3 factorial design.

Participants will judge the ethnoracial diversity (described to them as "ethnic/racial diversity") of each stimulus group. They will do so by clicking on a horizontal line labeled "Not Very Diverse" on the left end and "Very Diverse" on the right end. Their clicks will be converted to integers from 0 to 100, representing the proportion of the way along the line (from left to right) they clicked.

For each participant, we will compute the mean of the six diversity judgments for each of the nine combinations of objective ethnoracial and gender diversity. Thus, each participant's 54 diversity judgments will be reduced to nine aggregated judgments, and the ANOVA will be conducted on these aggregated judgments.

We will conduct a 3x3 repeated-measures ANOVA. We will evaluate the linear contrast for objective ethnoracial diversity, the linear contrast for objective gender diversity, and the interaction between these two linear effects.

q21.value: We will conduct two-tailed tests with an alpha level of .05. Note, however, that the preregistered hypothesis will be confirmed only if judgments of ethnoracial diversity *increase* as a function of gender diversity.

q22.value: We will exclude all data from any participant who does not make all 54 diversity judgments.

q23.value: Again, we will exclude all data from any participant who does not make all 54 diversity judgments.

The stimulus groups will vary in terms of their objective ethnoracial diversity (1 non-White person, 3 non-White people, or 5 non-White people) but also in terms of their objective gender diversity (1 woman, 3 women, or 5 women). Each of the nine unique combinations of ethnoracial and gender diversity will be presented six times--in a new randomized order for each participant--for a total of 54 trials. In essence, the design is a 3 (ethnoracial diverstiy) x 3 (gender diversity) within-subjects factorial design, with the dependent variable being judgments of ethnoracial diversity.
registration_responses.q12.question: The participants will be recruited from an introductory psychology subject pool at California State University, Fresno, and they will receive credit toward a class assignment for their participation. All participants who sign up for the study and then arrive to the lab on time will be tested on individual desktop computers. The entire procedure will take about 20 minutes. Testing will begin in February 2020 and last about a month.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the ethnoracial diversity of the stimulus groups; they will have either one, three, or five non-White people in them. We will also manipulate the gender diversity of the stimulus groups; they will have either one, three, or five women in them. Both of these variables will be manipulated within subjects in a 3x3 factorial design.
registration_responses.q17.question: Participants will judge the ethnoracial diversity (described to them as "ethnic/racial diversity") of each stimulus group. They will do so by clicking on a horizontal line labeled "Not Very Diverse" on the left end and "Very Diverse" on the right end. Their clicks will be converted to integers from 0 to 100, representing the proportion of the way along the line (from left to right) they clicked.
registration_responses.q18.question: For each participant, we will compute the mean of the six diversity judgments for each of the nine combinations of objective ethnoracial and gender diversity. Thus, each participant's 54 diversity judgments will be reduced to nine aggregated judgments, and the ANOVA will be conducted on these aggregated judgments.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will conduct a 3x3 repeated-measures ANOVA. We will evaluate the linear contrast for objective ethnoracial diversity, the linear contrast for objective gender diversity, and the interaction between these two linear effects.

q1.value: Messenger Effects, Goals, and Retirement Savings

q3.value:
The purpose of this study is to examine how different types of messengers and recommended actions influence people's retirement savings decisions. 

Prior research has shown that information from an authority figure or expert can influence as well as alter people’s behaviors (Cialdini, 1993). However, in the context of financial decision making and retirement savings, it seems that trust also plays a big role in determining who we look towards and listen to for advice (Lachance & Tang, 2012). According to a survey conducted by the Teachers Insurance and Annuities Association of America, people trust their employers for financial advice more so than their friends, family, and even financial advisors. Playing on this idea, it would be interesting to test if this finding replicates within an email setting. 

Furthermore, we are also interested in testing how different recommended actions, either a flat increase to 15% (target oriented action or goal) or an annual increase of 1% (growth oriented action or goal), influence people's retirement decisions. While the flat increase condition might serve as an anchor and consequently encourage individuals to contribute more to their retirement funds, it's plausible that individuals might view increasing their contributions to 15% as a far off and unattainable target. Consequently, a smaller annual increase of 1% might seem more attainable. We are interested in testing the relative efficacy of these two recommendations.

q4.value:
We expect that providing a benchmark contribution rate (target oriented action) or encouraging a 1% auto escalation (growth oriented action) will lead to more individuals increasing their retirement savings contributions compared to the control condition. We think that the growth oriented condition will outperform the target oriented condition. 

We also hypothesize that the employer recommendations will outperform the other messenger recommenders. We have no directional hypotheses for the remaining recommenders.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study will employ a 5x2 + 1 between subjects factorial design. We have two IVs: Recommendation source or messenger (none, employer, financial advisor, third party expert, generic advisor) and recommended action (flat increase i.e. target oriented, escalate contributions i.e. growth oriented). The 11 condition is a control condition in which there is no messenger and the recommended action is a generic increase.

q9.value: We randomized participants into the 11 conditions using a python script randomizer. First, all the UPS plan participants were randomized into all the conditions barring the 2 employer conditions. Next, we randomized the remaining participants into each of the 11 conditions. We checked to see if conditions were balanced across all relevant demographics (just the UPS ones, then just the remaining ones, and then all plans for the 9 non employer conditions).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Data will be obtained from Prudential's Participant Engagement Portal. Individuals in the Prudential participant pool will be sent emails containing the messaging manipulations. Specifically, employees of 5 organizations (Evonik Corporation, UPS, Lennar Corporation, MUFG Union Bank and Wipro Limited) will receive the intervention emails as a part of this experiment. The emails were sent out in the middle of December, 2019 and Prudential will conduct a data pull and provide relevant data in the middle of January, 2020. De-identified, anonymized data will be shared with the CAH team either through an encrypted email system or a secured Box folder.

q13.value: Our sample will consist of 80,681 participants, of which 52,806 are employed by UPS and 27,875 are employed by the remaining 4 organizations.

q14.value: Our sample size was determined by the capabilities of our field partner, Prudential. We did conduct an initial power analysis using the R pwr package. Assuming a 0.8 power, we would require a total of 1,639 individuals (for both our continuous and binary outcome measures). Given Prudential's capabilities and participant reach, we will be fully powered.

question.value: We have two IVs: Recommendation source (none, employer, financial advisor, third party expert, generic advisor) and recommended action (flat increase i.e. target oriented, escalate contributions i.e. growth oriented). These variables will be manipulated by altering the main recommendation headline in each email to reflect the appropriate condition.

We have several primary outcome variables:

Binary Variables:
Click to open rates: Measuring the number of individuals clicking on the CTA (out of those who opened the email) (1 if clicked on the CTA, 0 otherwise)
Take action: This variable measures whether or not the participant made any adjustments to their contributions following the email (1 if took action, 0 otherwise)
Increased: 1 if individual increased either % or $ contributions, 0 otherwise

Continuous Variables: 
Amount by which individuals altered contributions: Difference between initial contribution rate and new contribution rate ($ and %)
Amount by which individuals increased their contributions: For those who increased contributions, what is the difference between their initial and new contribution rates (% and $)

We will conduct several different analyses on different subsamples. Specifically, we will will first run our analysis on all the UPS affiliated participants (testing all conditions except for the employer conditions), then analyse the responses from the remaining 4 employer-affiliated individuals (all 11 conditions). Finally, we will conduct an analysis among all participants for the 9 non-"employer recommends" conditions.

Our analyses will be as follows:

Descriptive statistics for all variables


Just UPS: 9 conditions
CTA click rates by condition (logistic regression). 
Take action rates by condition (logistic regression). 
Choice to increase by condition (logistic regression). 
Change in contributions by condition (linear regression). 
Increase in contributions by condition (linear regression).


Just others: 11 conditions
CTA click rates by condition (logistic regression). 
Take action rates by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (logistic regression). 
Choice to increase by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (logistic regression). 
Change in contributions by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (linear regression). 
Increase in contributions by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (linear regression).


All employers: 9 conditions
CTA click rates by condition (logistic regression). 
Take action rates by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (logistic regression). 
Choice to increase by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (logistic regression). 
Change in contributions by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (linear regression). 
Increase in contributions by condition + interaction between condition and CTA (linear regression).

We will also conduct pairwise comparisons (t and Tukey HSD) to better understand how different conditions compare against one another.

q21.value: We will use p < 0.05 for determining whether the results from out analyses are significant.

q22.value: We will exclude individuals who did not receive our email (either a hard or soft bounceback). This data will also be provided by Prudential.

q23.value: Rows with missing or incomplete data will be excluded from our sample.

q24.value: We will also explore whether any of the demographic variables predict any of the outcome variables as well as whether one’s initial contribution rate moderates any of the conditional effects. In addition, we will examine whether any participants decreased their contributions in response to the emails and why that might be the case. Furthermore, we will explore whether the participants clicked any of the other links in the email and how, if at all, that affects their responses.

attributes.title: Management and outcomes following emergency surgery for traumatic brain injury – a multi-centre, international, prospective cohort study (the Global Neurotrauma Outcomes Study).
attributes.description: The primary aim of the study is to compare survival to discharge (or survival to 14 days post-operatively, whichever comes first) following emergency surgery for traumatic brain injury (TBI) across Human Development Index settings.

q1.value: Management and outcomes following emergency surgery for traumatic brain injury – a multi-centre, international, prospective cohort study (the Global Neurotrauma Outcomes Study).

q4.value: We hypothesise that 14-day mortality (or in-hospital mortality, if discharge occurs before 14 days) following emergency surgery for traumatic brain injury (TBI) will be higher in patients operated on in centres in countries with a lower Human Development Index.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a multi-centre, international, prospective, observational cohort study of all patients receiving emergency surgery for TBI in any consecutive 30-day period.  Local study teams may select any 30-day period from the 1st of November 2018 and the 31st of December 2019 to start their study.  Patients operated on who meet the inclusion criteria between 00:01 on day 0 and 23:59 on day 30 of the selected study period will be included.  The final study period will therefore begin on 31st December 2019 00:01 and end on 30th January 23:59.  Teams must follow patients up for 14-days from the date of surgery or until they are discharged or die – whichever of these comes first.  Final day of data collection for the primary outcome measure is therefore February 13th.  Teams have 30 days after the end of their selected study period to complete the data validation exercise (see below) – all patient level data should therefore be submitted to the central study team by 29th February.

The study protocol has been uploaded.  The protocol has been available on the www.globalneurotrauma.com website since prior to commencement of the study.

The study was registered on ClinicalTrials.gov and the Clinical Trials Registry - India.  ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT04212754.
CTRI number: CTRI/2019/02/017479

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: At the time of pre-registration, data collection is underway but not complete and data analysis has not commenced.  Data analysis will begin after the collection of centre level and patient level data has been completed.

question.value:
Study setting
Any hospital or clinic worldwide performing emergency surgery for traumatic brain injury is eligible to participate.  In the majority of institutions, emergency surgery for TBI is provided by neurosurgeons – however, centres in which emergency surgery for TBI is provided general surgeons, trauma surgeons, general medical doctors or even non-physician clinicians are also eligible to participate.

Patient inclusion criteria
All adult and paediatric patients admitted to the participating institution with a traumatic brain injury for which they receive emergency surgery during the selected 30-day inclusion period are eligible for inclusion in the study.  

Patient exclusion criteria
- Patients who ONLY have an external ventricular drain or intraparenchymal wire (or other monitoring device) inserted for the diagnosis and/or management of intracranial hypertension.  
- Patients who undergo procedures for chronic subdural haematoma(s), including burr holes or mini-craniotomies.
- Elective (planned admission) or semi-elective (where patient initially admitted as an emergency, then discharged from hospital, and re-admitted at later time for surgery) procedures.
- Patients who have previously had emergency cranial surgery for traumatic brain injury rendering them eligible for inclusion in this study (regardless of whether they were included)

Data points
A data set will be collected on all adult or paediatric patients receiving emergency surgery for TBI in the inclusion period (see tables 2 through 5).  The case report form is split into 3 sub-sections – injury/admission data, operative data and outcome data.  The data fields were based on existing data sets and refined through iterative consultation with an interdisciplinary consortium of clinicians caring for TBI across a range of HDI settings.

Finally, each local study lead will complete a provider profiling questionnaire on resources available for the pre-hospital, emergency department, surgical, intensive care and rehabilitation management of patients with acute brain injuries at their institution.  This questionnaire has been reviewed and endorsed by the WFNS Neurotraumatology Committee and British Neurotrauma Group.

Data capture
Collected data will be stored exclusively on a secure bespoke web-based system within the Outcome Registry Intervention and Operation Network (ORION) (https://orioncloud.org/).  The platform enables secure data collection, validation and storage in a standard (SQL) format and is compliant with NHS security standards (including the NHS Information Governance toolkit).  All patient data will be transmitted and held anonymously.  An internal pilot has been conducted using the platform to assess feasibility prior to roll out of the full study.  Prior to inputting data into the live platform, members of local study teams will be invited to practise entering ‘dummy’ data into an identical test platform with the aid of a comprehensive software guide.

Data quality
The protocol (including case report form and site questionnaire) has been translated, with the aid of global collaborators, into Arabic, Bengali, Chinese (traditional and simplified), French, Italian, Portuguese, Brazilian Portuguese, Spanish, Swahili and Urdu and to facilitate recruitment and participation from sites across the world.  A comprehensive data dictionary is also available at www.globalneurotrauma.com.  

Data validation
Data validation will occur by two mechanisms.  Firstly, web-based forms in the online data capture platform will contain fixed options at the point of data entry to maximise the likelihood of accurate and complete data capture from the outset.  Secondly, a local data validator independent of the local study team will be appointed at every participating site.  After the study period has ended, each data validator will be asked to retrospectively identify all patients who received emergency surgery for TBI in their centre’s study period (independent of the rest of the study team) to assess case ascertainment and collect data on 2 variables, namely the date and nature of the operation.

q13.value: As there is a paucity of data on emergency surgery for TBI globally, it was not possible to perform an accurate sample size calculation.  However, we expect between 100 and 200 centres to participate and expect the majority of these centres to collect data on 5–10 patients in a given 30-day study period.  This will result in a total of 500–2000 patients which we believe will be sufficient to analyse the study endpoints.

question.value:
The primary outcome measure will be 14-day mortality (or in-hospital mortality if discharge occurs before 14 days).

The secondary outcome measures will include:
1.	Perioperative complications
a.	Return to operating theatre during follow up period
b.	Surgical site infection (SSI)
2.	Length of stay (LOS)
a.	LOS in hospital (days)
b.	LOS in intensive care (days)
3.	Glasgow Coma Score at discharge (GCS-D)
4.	Discharge destination

The case report form, data dictionary and centre questionnaire have all been uploaded.

For the patient level data, an a priori statistical analysis plan has been developed with a statistician.  Mean and standard deviation will be reported for normally distributed variables and median and interquartile range for not normally distributed variables.  Participating centres will be stratified based on their country into groups based on their Human Development Index (HDI) rank.  The Human Development Index is calculated for each country based on its life expectancy at birth, years of schooling and gross national income (GNI) per capita (http://hdr.undp.org/en/composite/HDI).  14 day mortality (or survival to discharge, whichever comes first) will be reported for each HDI group and compared using the Pearson chi squared test.  Univariable logistic regression analyses will be conducted between covariates and the primary outcome measure. Based on the results, covariates with a p value of 0.20 will be included in the multivariable model. The final multivariable logistic model will be determined using stepwise backward elimination.  Pre-specified sub-group analyses will also be conducted for patients with severe TBI (GCS 3 to 8), and moderate and severe TBI (GCS 3 to 12).  Individual surgeons and hospitals will not be identifiable from analyses (unless explicit consent to do so is given).  Statistical analyses will be conducted using R (www.r-project.org).

q21.value: A p value of less than 0.05 will be considered statistically significant.

q2.value: Taylor Elise Petty, Rich Wiener, Megan Berry, Julie Wertheimer, Jasmine Martinez

q3.value:
Human trafficking constitutes one of the largest humanitarian crises on the global stage today. Even as law enforcement agents in the United States and beyond work to free victims from exploitation, there remains a variety of challenges for these victims after their liberation. Disinterest, misinformation, and even legal consequences can make it difficult for victims to come forward and be understood, and though the offenses of sex traffickers are particularly horrendous, many victims and their advocates face confusion and underwhelming emotional responses from policy makers and the public. As of 2010,
findings indicated that anti-trafficking efforts were for limited to enforcement only, resulting in many state parties continuing to arrest and detain trafficked persons. However, arrest of individuals for prostitution ends up punishing those who are coerced into the sex trade. The question of who constitutes a victim is one that individuals may disagree on, and when and
why the public views those who are trafficked as victims or perpetrators is one question this study hopes to answer. There remains a scarcity of literature and empirical research on emotion work in regard to sex trafficking, specifically emotional reactions to sex trafficking victims. This study will add to the literature on how people perceive and emotionally respond sex trafficking victims, and how those perceptions and responses inform sex-trafficking verdict decisions.

q4.value:
1. All participants will find the defendant guilty of sex trafficking.  
2. Participants will find the vulnerable as compared to non-vulnerable victim less likely to be guilty of prostitution, less likely to be arrested, and more likely to receive services. 
3. Participants will find the victim who engaged in prostitution prior to the trafficking as compared to the victim who did not engage in prostitution prior more likely to be guilty of prostitution, more likely to be arrested, and less likely to receive services. 
4. There will be a two-way interaction between vulnerability and prior prostitution in accordance with Wiener et al. (2020) such that participants who read about the non-vulnerable victim who did not engage in prior prostitution will be most likely to be guilty of prostitution, most likely to be arrested, and least likely to receive services. 
5. Affective forecasting will moderate all of the above relationships such that they will be stronger for those individuals who did engage in affective forecasting.
6. Negative affective forecast about the victim returning to prostitution will predict judgements of prostitution culpability, arrest likelihood and service provision. In other words, those affective forecasters who anticipate feeling negative emotions and especially mood upon finding out that the survivor returned to prostitution will be most likely to find her guilty of prostitution, most likely to favor arrest and least likely to offer services. This will not be true of experienced emotions and mood at least not to the extent that anticipated emotions and mood are predictive of the above judgements.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study is a 2 (Vulnerability: high vs. low) x 2 (Pre-incident prostitution: presence vs. absence) x 2 (Affective forecasting: presence vs. absence) between-subjects design.

q9.value: The randomization will occur through the Qualtrics Website (i.e., through randomized blocks). The website will randomly assign participants to one of four conditions. Some materials within conditions will be presented in random order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study presents a vignette and asks participants to evaluate it. We will recruit participants from Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Participants will provide responses online through Qualtrics. Participants will be paid $0.50 for completion of the study.

q13.value: We will recruit approximately 600 participants for this study. All participants' data will be analyzed.

q14.value: The proposed sample size (N=600) provides 95% power to detect a small effect size (.15) at p = .05.

q15.value: Amazon's Mechanical Turk allows us to specify the exact number of participants.

question.value:
Victim Past Vulnerability: High or Low
Pre-incident prostitution involvement: Yes or No
Affective Forecasting: Presence or Absence

The Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS) with subscales measuring anger, fear, disgust, and pride. 
Questionnaire assessing the participants' perception of the legality of the situation
described in the vignette.
Demographics

Data will be downloaded from the Qualtrics website into the SPSS platform. After cleaning and checking the data, we will analyze the percentage of participants who passed manipulation and attention checks, removing participants as necessary. We will perform a 2 (vulnerability: high vs low) x 2 (pre-incident prostitution: yes vs no) x 2 (affective forecasting: present vs absent) factorial ANOVA for the independent variables on verdict certainty. Exploratory mediation and moderation analyses will be performed through Process or through Mplus statistical software

q21.value: We will use two-tailed p-value tests and confidence intervals for inference criteria.

q22.value: Participants who take too little time (less than 2 SD below the average time) or too long time (more than 2 SD above the average time) will be excluded. Participants who fail too many attention checks will also be excluded.

q23.value: We will drop participants who have too much missing data to compute meaningful analyses.

q2.value: Athanasios Vasileios Kokkinakis, Peter York, Matthew Alexander Whitby, Alex Wade, Tom Stafford, Ozan vardal

q3.value:
Many studies have linked fluid intelligence, rotational  and numerical ability as well as Age with performance in both traditional games (e.g. chess) as well as video games.

We will replicate and extend previous studies with a wider battery of psychometric intelligence tests as well as a  sample size collected from a range of  online communities. In addition, we will include a short personality questionnaire. We will correlate all the measures with self-reported Rankings across four videogame genres (MOBAs, RTS, Fighting and FPS). We will additionally construct a "g-factor" and correlate that with videogame Rank, expecting a positive correlation (reaction times will be negatively correlated). We will also ask whether videogame performance  peaks in one's twenties as predicted and if it is strongly linked to IQ.

q4.value:
Before we start we need to define how performance is measured in  the videogames we are studying. All games have a form of ranking called Matchmaking Rating (MMR) that is primarily based on winning/losing and is numerical. The higher the MMR the better the player is considered at the game (or at least at winning).

Recently videogames have adopted a system where a player's MMR is hidden or is not readily available to the player and it has been replaced by a form of Divisions/Tiers/Medals. These are discrete variables that are not perfectly accurate and they represent an MMR Range that the player belongs to. For instance a player in a fictional videogame coud be Wood Tier,  Division 1 with his MMR lying anywhere in the range of 100 to 400 MMR whereas a player that is Wood Tier, Division 2 (a Rank above) could have his MMR range from 350 to 600. Thus some partial random overlap is expected (at least when it comes to small samples). In larger samples we expect that this random effect will cancel itself out. 

Here whenever we refer to Ranks or Performance we refer to each game's in-game Ranking Label (Divisions,Tiers, Medals etc). Dota 2 is an exception, since aside from the Medals (In-game Rank),  a player's MMR  is displayed in the "Stats" Tab which we will additionally use.

We have the following hypotheses:

Directional :

All tests that correlate positively with IQ will also correlate positively with rank. Specifically:


1) The Matrix Reasoning test will be positively correlated with Rank ( the r might range from 0.2 to 0.4 depending on how range restricted the sample is). (Kokkinakis, Cowling, Drachen & Wade, 2017)
2) The numerical test will be positively correlated with Rank (Bonny JW, Castaneda, 2016).
3) The rotational test will be positively correlated with Rank (Adams & Mayer, 2012).
4) The Figural Analogy Test will be positively correlated with Rank.
5) The Santa Barbara Solids Test will be positively correlated with Rank.
6)The modded HMT will be positively correlated.

In addition : 

6)The simple Reaction Time tests will be negatively correlated with Rank (faster people reach higher Ranks).

7) The complex Reaction Time tests will be negatively correlated with Rank (again faster people will reach higher Rank). 
8) When we measure personality with the HEXACO-60, we expect Emotionality a construct which is similar yet not identical to Neuroticism to be negatively correlated with Rank (pilot data).
9) A g will be constructed with the Intelligence tests (Jensen & Weng, 1994). This will be positively correlated with Rank.
10) We believe that,if we plot performance against age for all these types of videogames, we will see a peak and then a  decline into old age (Kokkinakis, Cowling, Drachen & Wade, 2017; Tekofsky, 2015; Thompson et al., 2014).
11) We expect Maximal Rank achieved to follow a similar pattern as Current Rank (the variable mentioned above as "Rank").

Non-directional/Other:

12) We will ask participants to estimate their Maximum Rank they could achieve if they dedicated enough time to "grind games". This is purely exploratory to see if individuals have realistic estimates of their abilities.
13) A stepwise regression for each individual genre.
14) Intraindividual variability of Simple and Complex Reaction times.

q5.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Our experiment will be advertised online in various communities that have a high videogame population such as Reddit. We will additionally advertise the experiment through word of mouth and through the University of York pages and possibly other universities (Sheffiled and Essex).

We are going to use a website to collect the data. We will be using a combination of the Unity, Qualtrics and google forms. 


Our participants will be over 18.

Our participants will be experienced videogame players. 


All our players will have been asked to have played ranked games.

q8.value: We will not limit our sample size. We are aiming at over 1,000 individuals for each videogame genre.

q9.value:
As mentioned above certain correlations are predicted to be quite weak (Simple Reaction times, Emotionality-Rank) thus a large number of individuals are required.

Moreover, we may need a bigger sample due to the possibility of restricted sampling (an overabundance of average to above average individuals). Finally, data collected through this experiment might be used to aid some researchers' thesis chapters so time is relatively limited.



I could detect an r of 0.05 with 0.05 confidence interval with 1530 according to this paper.

Moinester, M., & Gottfried, R. (2014). Sample size estimation for correlations with pre-specified confidence interval. The Quantitative Methods for Psychology, 10(2), 124-130.

However, regarding the g correlation a smaller sample of 500 to 800 may be more than sufficient based on this paper.


Large, A. M., Bediou, B., Cekic, S., Hart, Y., Bavelier, D., & Green, C. S. (2019). Cognitive and behavioral correlates of achievement in a complex multi-player video game. Media and Communication, 7(4), 198-212

q10.value: We will also stop collecting Data after 20 weeks or if a large number of participants is acquired. Note that part of the data may be used for a journal paper in early May while we keep collecting them.

question.value: This is a correlational study.

We are going to measure the correct responses for each test. Although we are talking about IQ, since the game ladder has individuals of all ages playing the game we will use RAW/unnormalised Scores of the following variables taken by the ICAR project :

ICAR Tests:

Figural Analogies
Matrix Reasoning Puzzles
Number Series
Three Dimensional Rotation Cubes/Test
Santa Barbara Test


Other:

HMT-S Moded (Hagen Matrices)
Replication:

Emotionality (HEXACO-60) Scored according to the authors instructions, taking into account negatively scored questions.


Reaction time tests

Simple Reaction time test (Median Reaction Time,  Intraindividual reaction time variability).
Complex Reaction Time (Variant of the Odd-man out Paradigm).
Here we will record : A) Intraindividual reaction time variability B) Median Reaction Time C) Number of Mistakes (Wrong Buttton Pressed)


Practice

Practice will be positively correlated with Rank. Here we will record a) Percentage of hours spend improving b) total hours and matches played

We are going to use a Principal Components Analysis to derive a g . Due to the stability of g and the nature of rotation, we believe that our results will be highly robust (Jensen & Weng, 1994). We are going to use an oblique rotation (Promax).

q14.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Correlational Study. Each videogame Rank will be treated as unique and will be correlated with the performance test and with the derived g factor.

Although we will manipulate the order of presentation of the test in the initial page. Each individual will be asked to fill out the tests at their leisure, therefore no explicit counterbalancing will be used. Although since individuals will do their tests at their own time we expect that fatigue effects will be minimal.

q17.value: We are not doing a randomised study.

question.value:
We will firstly run a Pearson's correlation between  the Ranks and the Psychometric Intelligence tests. We expect all performance tests to be intercorrelated with each other as predicted by the literature (Positive Manifold) (van der Maas et al., 2006; Jensen, 1992). 

Reaction Time measures will be negatively correlated since faster participants have been reported to score higher in intelligence tests. We expect the same negative correlation between Emotionality and Rank.


We have previously used a Spearman's Correlation in our studies due to the nature of Rankings.  We expect that due to the large number of participantPearson's r will be suitable and near identical to Spearman rho.

q20.value: We may need to merge the Iron categories with the lower bronze 5 categories if we are trying to do a max rank analysis (since iron was recently introduced).

q21.value:
We will examine ages and Rank. We believe that the peak rank will be in one's twenties there will be a steady decline past the age of 30-35. We will run a one-way ANOVA for each individual game (each game should be treated as its own 'ecosystem'/environment).

If the participant has provided us with both their Age and the time the time they peaked, a similar analysis will be performed. We expect similar results as above. We do expect a smoother decline with aging and rank with what has been previously observed.

q22.value: Due to the sample size we are aiming for p values will be less than .001 . Even though it appears that we are using a multitude of Performance Tests it should be noted that they are intercorrelated (Positive Manifold) and it is customary in the literature to use a large number of tests.  We will be using one tailed tests between any type of Rank and Intelligence since we are expecting a positive relationship as evidenced in the literature (better individuals tend to reach higher ranks). We will be using however a two-tailed tests in all of the exploratory analyses described below (for instance when looking at the difference between Starcraft 2 Races).

q23.value:
Full Participant Rejection:

All-Questionnaires :

We will additionally remove participants that have continuously pressed the same Response in a row (3,3,3,3,3 etc). This could happen because of 'Botting' or because they 'flicker through' the experiment or even because they are guessing the answer rathen than click the "I don't know button" in order to get a better score.


We will fully remove participants that submit the ID of a professional player that currently plays in any Major Tournaments (LCS, The International, Dota 2 Major/Minor) unless they personally contact us to verify their scores (by mailing us the ID we gave them).


Multivariate Outlier Rejection

We are going to use Mahalanobis Distances to remove outliers. The variables we are going to be using are Figural Analogies, Matrix Reasoning, the Three Dimensional Rotation, the modified HMT and Current Rank ( this will be run seperately for each genre, using the game that participants have invested the most time in or the one they reported to have the highest rank at).

We will perform and outlier rejection between rank and age as well.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Outlier Rejection:

Reaction Times:

For individual participants : we will firstly remove any RT responses that are below 150 ms. This is not a hard set rule but studies suggest removal of responses that are between the 100-250 ms limit due to guessing. 150 ms appears to be appropriate (Hultsch et al., 2000; Garrett et al., 2011)

We will subsequently remove RTs over 1s (Frearson, & Eysenck, 1986).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Intelligence Tests:

We will inspect the distributions. If they appear normal we will use Tukey’s outlier technique (k=2.2) on the Completion Time. We believe that this will help filter out individuals that a)  flickered through the tests b) created bots to autofill the questionnaires c) took too much time perhaps using aids to finish certain tasks (such as pen and paper) or googled the answers etc.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In-game Rank

We will exclude individuals that haven't played enough ranked games.

We will similarly partially exclude individuals who achieved their peak Rank more than 4 years ago.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

References:


Hultsch, D. F., MacDonald, S. W., Hunter, M. A., Levy-Bencheton, J., & Strauss, E. (2000). Intraindividual variability in cognitive performance in older adults: comparison of adults with mild dementia, adults with arthritis, and healthy adults. Neuropsychology, 14(4), 588.

Garrett, D. D., Kovacevic, N., McIntosh, A. R., & Grady, C. L. (2011). The importance of being variable. The Journal of Neuroscience : The Official Journal of the Society for Neuroscience, 31(12), 4496–4503. http://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5641-10.2011

Frearson, W., & Eysenck, H. J. (1986). Intelligence, reaction time (RT) and a new ‘odd-man-out’RT paradigm. Personality and Individual Differences, 7(6), 807-817.

q24.value:
We will completely remove any participants that have completed less than three visuospatial tasks or haven't filled in their Rank info; if they have given us their profile and we are able to extract it, we will include them. One of the key reasons we are doing this study is to replicate our previous findings between visuospatial intelligence and videogame Rank.

If the participant has completed 3 or more visuospatial tests we will impute the missing values in order to create the g factor.

 
We expect a large number of drop outs or null results simply due to attrition or people who are not part of our targeted demographics just clicking through the tests. Thus if we perform a Missing Value Analysis our data may appear biased due to the aforementioned causes yet still that bias will not really be meaningful.

If a participant has not completed a specific test, their score will simply not be generated for that test and the Task will be counted as null for them (for that particular statistical test).

q25.value:
We might look at the range restricted correlations. Either through this method : https://www.personality-project.org/r/psych/help/range.correction.html

Or by bootstrapping our sample (if range restricted) in order to resemble more an already known distribution of IQ or MMR.

q27.value: These data are part of a much wider data gathering exercise. However, we may opt to start writing a journal paper about it and using the data that have been collected at the start of May.

Even though it appears that we are using a multitude of Performance Tests it should be noted that they are intercorrelated (Positive Manifold) and it is customary in the literature to use a large number of tests.  We will be using one tailed tests between any type of Rank and Intelligence since we are expecting a positive relationship as evidenced in the literature (better individuals tend to reach higher ranks). We will be using however a two-tailed tests in all of the exploratory analyses described below (for instance when looking at the difference between Starcraft 2 Races).
registration_responses.q23:
Full Participant Rejection:

All-Questionnaires :

We will additionally remove participants that have continuously pressed the same Response in a row (3,3,3,3,3 etc). This could happen because of 'Botting' or because they 'flicker through' the experiment or even because they are guessing the answer rathen than click the "I don't know button" in order to get a better score.


We will fully remove participants that submit the ID of a professional player that currently plays in any Major Tournaments (LCS, The International, Dota 2 Major/Minor) unless they personally contact us to verify their scores (by mailing us the ID we gave them).


Multivariate Outlier Rejection

We are going to use Mahalanobis Distances to remove outliers. The variables we are going to be using are Figural Analogies, Matrix Reasoning, the Three Dimensional Rotation, the modified HMT and Current Rank ( this will be run seperately for each genre, using the game that participants have invested the most time in or the one they reported to have the highest rank at).

We will perform and outlier rejection between rank and age as well.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Outlier Rejection:

Reaction Times:

For individual participants : we will firstly remove any RT responses that are below 150 ms. This is not a hard set rule but studies suggest removal of responses that are between the 100-250 ms limit due to guessing. 150 ms appears to be appropriate (Hultsch et al., 2000; Garrett et al., 2011)

We will subsequently remove RTs over 1s (Frearson, & Eysenck, 1986).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Intelligence Tests:

We will inspect the distributions. If they appear normal we will use Tukey’s outlier technique (k=2.2) on the Completion Time. We believe that this will help filter out individuals that a)  flickered through the tests b) created bots to autofill the questionnaires c) took too much time perhaps using aids to finish certain tasks (such as pen and paper) or googled the answers etc.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In-game Rank

We will exclude individuals that haven't played enough ranked games.

We will similarly partially exclude individuals who achieved their peak Rank more than 4 years ago.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

References:


Hultsch, D. F., MacDonald, S. W., Hunter, M. A., Levy-Bencheton, J., & Strauss, E. (2000). Intraindividual variability in cognitive performance in older adults: comparison of adults with mild dementia, adults with arthritis, and healthy adults. Neuropsychology, 14(4), 588.

Garrett, D. D., Kovacevic, N., McIntosh, A. R., & Grady, C. L. (2011). The importance of being variable. The Journal of Neuroscience : The Official Journal of the Society for Neuroscience, 31(12), 4496–4503. http://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5641-10.2011

Frearson, W., & Eysenck, H. J. (1986). Intelligence, reaction time (RT) and a new ‘odd-man-out’RT paradigm. Personality and Individual Differences, 7(6), 807-817.
registration_responses.q24:
We will completely remove any participants that have completed less than three visuospatial tasks or haven't filled in their Rank info; if they have given us their profile and we are able to extract it, we will include them. One of the key reasons we are doing this study is to replicate our previous findings between visuospatial intelligence and videogame Rank.

If the participant has completed 3 or more visuospatial tests we will impute the missing values in order to create the g factor.

 
We expect a large number of drop outs or null results simply due to attrition or people who are not part of our targeted demographics just clicking through the tests. Thus if we perform a Missing Value Analysis our data may appear biased due to the aforementioned causes yet still that bias will not really be meaningful.

If a participant has not completed a specific test, their score will simply not be generated for that test and the Task will be counted as null for them (for that particular statistical test).

registration_responses.q13.question: We are going to use a Principal Components Analysis to derive a g . Due to the stability of g and the nature of rotation, we believe that our results will be highly robust (Jensen & Weng, 1994). We are going to use an oblique rotation (Promax).
registration_responses.q16.question:
Correlational Study. Each videogame Rank will be treated as unique and will be correlated with the performance test and with the derived g factor.

Although we will manipulate the order of presentation of the test in the initial page. Each individual will be asked to fill out the tests at their leisure, therefore no explicit counterbalancing will be used. Although since individuals will do their tests at their own time we expect that fatigue effects will be minimal.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will firstly run a Pearson's correlation between  the Ranks and the Psychometric Intelligence tests. We expect all performance tests to be intercorrelated with each other as predicted by the literature (Positive Manifold) (van der Maas et al., 2006; Jensen, 1992). 

Reaction Time measures will be negatively correlated since faster participants have been reported to score higher in intelligence tests. We expect the same negative correlation between Emotionality and Rank.


We have previously used a Spearman's Correlation in our studies due to the nature of Rankings.  We expect that due to the large number of participantPearson's r will be suitable and near identical to Spearman rho.
